description: From Middle English goot, got, gat, from Old English gāt, from Proto-West Germanic *gait, from Proto-Germanic *gaits, from a substrate language.
The sense of lecherous man derives from the slang expression "horny as a goat".

definitionGroups.group: A mammal, Capra aegagrus hircus, and similar species of the genus Capra.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The meat of the aforementioned animal.
examples: Ugh, we're having goat for dinner again.
Fernando Rodney, the goat in Sunday's 10th inning loss to Tampa Bay, threw three nearly perfect innings in relief on Tuesday after being demoted from the closer role.

entries.meaning: (speech recognition) A person who is not easily understood by a speech recognition system; contrasted with sheep.
A fool, loser, or object of ridicule.
(roller derby) A blocker who is isolated behind the opposing team's blockers, so as to slow down the pack.
(acronym) Alternative letter-case form of GOAT (“Greatest of All Time”)

verbs.description: goat (third-person singular simple present goats, present participle goating, simple past and past participle goated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To allow goats to feed on.
examples: Rape and clover has yielded 283 sheep days of pasture, practically dry weather  […]  For the coming year it is planned to goat this area continuously
John Rocker, meanwhile, was spared from getting goated because he didn't blow a save

entries.meaning: (transitive, roller derby) To isolate (an opposing blocker) behind one's own blockers, so as to slow down the pack.
